creator: apache.bugzilla@abcdatos.com
text:
Using mod_speling under 2.0.45, if the request is ended in "/", purposed 
documents are also ended in "/", no matter if they are files or directories.

Example:

   We look for URI "http://www.abcdatos.com/programas/traductores/". 
The "traductores" directory doesn't exist, and the only similar file is:

-rw-rw-r-- traductores.html

   The reply odtained is:

HTTP/1.1 300 Multiple Choices
[...]
Multiple Choices
The document name you requested (/programas/traductores/) could not be found 
on this server. However, we found documents with names similar to the one you 
requested.
Available documents: 

/programas/traductores.html/ (common basename) 

   The file traductores.html is ok, but the link is showing also "/", like if 
it was a directory. Following this link, directly causes 404 error. The 
correct response is:

/programas/traductores.html

Thanks and good luck!
Just curious: what happens if you configure AcceptPathInfo Off for the location?
creator: nd@perlig.de
apache.bugzilla@abcdatos.com
text:
Tried adding AcceptPathInfo Off and also AcceptPathInfo On in the <Location> 
and <VirtualHost> sections caused no difference in "multiple choices" page 
content nor in the 404 error if folowing the link shown with the final bracket 
added.

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
Fixed in 2.1. mod_speling recognizes the Acceptpathinfo setting for the particular 
location and rejects path info by default. 
 
It's not really critical (you may set up workarounds, like Redirects and/or RewriteRules) 
so it's unlikely to be backported to the 2.0 stable branch. 
 
Thanks for using Apache!
